turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in 73-1942, Erznoznik against Jacksonville.
Mr. Maness, you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
This is an appeal from a judgment of the highest court of the State of Florida in which a decision could be hand which decision upheld the unconstitutionally of the Jacksonville City ordinance.
Which makes it unlawful ad provides, it is hereby declared a public nuisance to exhibit for certain persons to exhibit.

Any motion picture in which the human male or female bare buttocks, human female bare breast or human bare pubic areas are shown if such motion picture is visible from any public street or public place.
My client, Richard Erznoznik is the manager of the University Drive-In Theater.

In 1972 shortly after the passage of this ordinance, he was charge with knowingly exhibiting a motion picture in which the human female buttocks and bare breast was shown said scenes being visible from a public street or a public place, and it was summons to appear in Court April 6, 1972.

He appeared and by stipulation, the prosecution was stayed in order that we might test the constitutionality of this ordinance by an action for declaratory judgment in the Circuit Court of two-old-county which is the highest trial court.
We filed that complaint, we had our trial.

The trial court upheld the constitutionality of the statute the District Court of Appeals affirmed relying upon the Chemline case from the First Circuit Court of Appeals and the Supreme Court of Florida denied certiorari by 4-3 vote.
Now, little more that it be said than has been said in my brief and the brief of amicus Motion Picture Association of America.

What I would like to emphasize is the total failure of those who drafted this ordinance and the Florida Courts that have construed it to sharpen its focus and confine its proscriptions, so as not to censor or punish protected speech.

We do not question the basic constitutional panel of the states and the cities to enact laws which punish or inhibit unprotected speech or which protect unwilling persons against obtrusive public displays of explicit sexual material which are both grossly offensive and unavoidable.
But we do contend that such laws must be carefully drawn or authoritatively construed, so that they are not susceptible to application to speech protected by the First and the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Maness, Sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: If this still had been shown in a close theater, you wouldn’t be here would you?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: I would not.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: So?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: This was an ‘R’ rated film, the class of 74.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
I was wondering while this isn’t in a time and place issue rather than the First Amendment one.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, the reason, we don't think it’s a time and place issue.
We did plead that and announce it for declaratory decree is because basically, it gets down to whether or not the city council has the power to declare whatever it pleases a public nuisance.
And in this instance, they've chosen to declare the mere showing of these anatomical parts a nuisance.
So that it seems to me --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Public, public showing is the issue?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: As showing on an outdoor movie screen visible from a public place.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Wait, Mr. Maness, what if the ordinance merely provided that it would be an offense to exhibit any movie of any kind that was visible from any public street or public place.
Would that be more objectionable or constitutionally or less so?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: I would say it's be equally objectionable because that seeks to in -- assuming that it's declared a public nuisance also.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, the same ordinance as what you have except that it just says any movie of any kind.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: I would say it's an unlawful infringement on protected speech, visual portrayals because --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Why wouldn't it be a perfectly good ordinance regulating traffic safety, you don't want people driving down the street looking at movies?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, if it were related to traffic safety --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And why wouldn't --

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Then, well it wouldn’t be unless it was so construed.
If by its very language it just says, “It shall be unlawful to exhibit on an outdoor screen visible from a public place of movie.”

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, visible from any public street.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: A movie.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I think any movie, yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, I think you’d have to show that there’s some relationship between --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Oh, wouldn't there be for a rational relationship?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: I don't think so.
Unless you said, where the exhibition is visible from a traveled highway and there is a showing --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But, generally public streets are traveled, aren't they?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: More or less.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: I would not -- I would say there's no relationship.
The social benefit to be derived from prohibiting any movie visible from any public place, it seemed to me is not outweighed in the traffic sense.
It does not out weigh the First Amendment --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, -- for the legislature to make or initially as to which social benefit weighs most heavily if it’s acting rationally?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, if it is -- yes, if it's acting rationally.
Yes, if there’s --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Why I suppose if the matters if this ordinance could not be applied as the motion picture for example, that was exhibited at the time was Snow White, could it?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: No, it could not.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: So, to that extent, there's a distinction going would suggest that the purpose of this ordinance does not traffic safety.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Correct.
I was answering the speculated question but the purpose of this ordinance is definitely not traffic safety.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So this ordinance, we would say is more objectionable under the First and the Fourteenth Amendment then it might have it after all it would be.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Much more.
As I would -- If I get that far, as I --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, let me ask you another question.
How can you be that positive if it's not traffic safety?
Isn't it permissible for the Jacksonville City Council to say that bare breast and bare buttock maybe more distracting to drivers along the highway than the picture of Snow White?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Yes, if they'd said that or if the Courts had construed that into it, maybe.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but why they -- why does the legislature have to say all the reasons behind it?
I mean, if an argument can now be advanced that supports the rationality, but what more does this Court need?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, the same rationale that we've been talking about in defining word cases.
That is that while you may construe that way and uphold its validity, it may not be applied that way by the police officer or the prosecutor who makes the charge.
He may bring the prosecution simply because he's opposed to nudity in any form, in any time, in any place.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what do you think of the motives?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What do we care about the motives?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Not his motive --

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: If we are, as I understand the protect -- protection we afford speech in this country.

We are concerned about the motives of the persons who seek to inhibit it by some means other than no ordinance or a law that’s narrowly drawn or authoritatively construed to get at only unprotected speech or unprotected conduct.
Now, if you can put a law of books that can be construed in a half of dozen ways, then we violate that principle.
If that principle is to be violated, then this Court can say so.
But, it seems to me if you compare this to the defining words cases, you have to say, if the City of Jacksonville wants to do that.
They've got to draw this ordinance more carefully or it's got to be authoritatively construed not to infringe on otherwise protected speech.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Would you say that the City of Jacksonville could go beyond what has been called obscene by this Court and make a broader proscription.
And just obscenity when you're talking about projecting it beyond the theater walls to the public?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Yes, I think they'd probably could something more obscene then mere nudity.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, something less obscene than what this Court has said can be prohibited by the State within the walls of the theater where everybody is consented to see it.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, that's a very difficult question to answer because I have tried to figure out how this ordinance could have been authoritatively construed in the Florida Courts to achieve a purpose that does not trench upon protected speech and I don’t see how it can.
I don't see how you can draw such an ordinance.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is protected speech as you're using it?
Is it anything that's not obscene?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: No.

It's anything that this Court has held unprotected such as lewd and obscene, profane, libelous, insulting, confiding words, words which are very arrogant, not words portray or portrayals or pictures that tend to insight immediate breach of the peace or something of that sort.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But then you're saying that Jacksonville can't prohibit in an outdoor movie that's projected beyond the walls that of the theater.
Anything that it couldn't prohibit in an indoor movie?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: No, I'm not really saying that.
I don't intend to say that.
I intend -- what I intend to say is that if they relate it to something that isn't in fact a nuisance.
They can prohibit images on a screen that would create dangers to the citizens.
But --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: But don't you think Mr. Maness, for example that there are circumstances in which a state might say as to an open-air movie.
Now, that even an exhibition of a picture in which react to simply recite the First Amendment.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: They could prohibit it just like they could prohibit outdoor and in other words, they could prohibit outdoor theaters.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: In the interest to safety?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: I suppose they could.
But until they decide to prohibit outdoor theaters that --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Can we be so very sure that is what you're talking about?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, I think so, there's we have

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What about that, what about the nude performances in the public park.

Let's say there's a summer play series in the public park where and it's a municipal -- it's in the park and -- but there's a law that says as long as you’re showing it in an open-air and people can come and go unless it's public, no nudity.
No nudes in this summer plays in the park, is that too bad?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, as I read.

I think it's a question of -- I think the city fathers could decide that question like they've decided they don't own some of the beaches down in Florida but they even had a vote as to whether or not --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, you would say that’s acceptable?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Acceptable with the proper words --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it's saying, if you're going to walk down the street, wear some clothes.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Yes, at this point in history.
I think it probably is.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you think the City could have an ordinance prohibiting soundtracks from operating during hours, let us say after 10 o’clock at night?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Yes, I think so.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Or at anytime that the sound level was over a certain decibel level?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: I think so.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But what if -- what if the candidates running for public office and he wants to make a speech?
That's one of the highest forms of the First Amendment right, isn't it?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: It is but you know, it's the question who's making the judgment in a --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But you concede that if it annoys, if it's loud enough so that rationally it can be said that this annoys a lot of people and maybe affects their hearing but then it can be prohibited.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, I'm under the impression that under the rules laid down by this Court that such an ordinance could be narrowly drawn authoritatively construed and upheld.
Eventhough, it does in trench strongly on First Amendment rights.
But I don't really see the parallel between that and mere nudity on an outdoor movie screen if you’re going to have any films of any kind.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But if the city fathers that what you view the screen is that it's all located that anybody wants to have nice speech of stop and watch the entire movie.
And the fact is that at this corner the children gather --

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: If there was --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: To watch the movies and if they're going -- if you want your screen in that location, just don't show x-rated movies.
If the kids are going to -- you're going to let the kids gather outside and watch this -- this -- if you want to just keep -- just clean up your movies a little bit.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, if they passed an ordinance such as you're speaking of and related it specifically to traffic problems --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's not what I'm talking about.
I'm talking about children.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Alright, if they related the ordinance to children?
I think they might very well come up with an ordinance that could stand constitutional master.
But this ordinance is no related to any of those things.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What would happen to the case as that -- who is watching these movies?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: That, yes, but the children would be outside watching the movies if it was Mary Poppins

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh, I know.
That and nobody objects to that saying, City Council --

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: No.
Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Agrees to that showing is -- the parents in town object to the screen showing x-rated movies to their children?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, we're not talking about x-rated movie.
We're talking about one hour movie, the class of ’74.
This is not a --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh, I know but your position covers all -- covers x-rated movies or any other related movie, so let's don’t --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So that is an ‘R’ rated movie up to the time to decide whether the child goes or not?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, under 17.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, the child and the parent had no jurisdiction of whether the child stands on the corner, will see it?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, you know we have other laws that such as laws against trespass and littering, and other ways of permitting those who are inside the theater to see what they want to see without interference from those outside the theater.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But this is restricted to be outside?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: This ordinance is restricted, so restricted yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And it merely says that you shouldn't show this picture to children without their parent's consent?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall, it doesn't mentioned children.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I know it doesn't but that’s what happened.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, I doubt it that’s what happened.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you don't say children are interested in watching ‘R’ rated movies.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: I think the children go in and they want to see it.
You know, they get their parents permission, they get in car and they go in.
But that’s beside the point, of course --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It is beside the point because mine is when the parents say, “Don’t go to that theater.”
And then the child said, “Where, well I won’t go to the theater to see it.”
And he just goes to the corner and looks for free.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: This is right--

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: That happens.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that’s part of what this ordinance is aimed at.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: But if he was looking at this --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It isn't part of what this ordinance is aimed at?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Yes.

And if he were looking at a travel law of foreign lands, or art museums, or a health picture, or even a news room, he might also see a bare female breast, or bare male or female buttocks and that would be the end of the movie.
So, the point is, can the movie be suppress simply and solely because it has scenes of this anatomical parts in it regardless of the context.
And it seems to me that this case falls right in with the whole line of cases of this Court --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Let's get back to my Brother Rehnquist's point.
I mean, the average person driving on the street if he sees a bare buttocks on the wall over there, he’s going to look at it.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, if he recognizes it as such.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I would assume that the average person can recognize this.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, I've driven by these movie screens.
And I am only speaking from my own experience and I have seen figures on the screen and not really known what they were.
I didn't give that much of an attention to it.
You see movement, you see flashes, and you see color.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You're suggesting that in order to sustain one statute it must be demonstrated that it's reaches perfect candidate to either that or in combination with other statutes.
All such conduct is completely prescribed and prohibited while there's no such doctrine of laws out, is there?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: No.
Not that broad.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Statutes against murder is to survive eventhough in murders are continued at a very great rate.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: And we define the degrees of murder, first, second, third, manslaughter, justifiable or excusable homicide.
But we don't define the degrees of offense that we commit when one scene of nudity comes on the screen.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Maness, what is the consequence of under this ordinance if the establishment is declared a nuisance?
Is it just that he is convicted of maintaining a public nuisance?
Is it a misdemeanor?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: It's a low grade misdemeanor.
But it's not a matter of establishing the theater as being a nuisance.
It just simply --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Showing of --

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: It subjects the projectionist or the manager or ticket taker, someone of those to a criminal penalty.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, so that the word nuisance in there is sort of passage in the sense the ordinance could've said, whoever shows on a screen visible to the public street commits a misdemeanor?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: I would say that that's pretty much correct but --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it doesn't -- I mean, it doesn't have the consequence, ordinary consequence with news of being able to shut it down?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: No.
It does not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It doesn't permit the city to shut down --

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: It says, it's unlawful and hereby declared a public nuisance to do this.
But the public nuisance doctrine, I think is the justification for inhibiting it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But usually you're beating nuisances.

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But indeed it does --

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: It's the right.
They usually do but in this --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the only thing that's a nuisance is that that single showing or whatever it is?

turn.speaker: william_h_maness
turn.label: Mr. William H. Maness
turn.text: Well, I don't think that's not even a nuisance.
That's just the basis on which they justify make another penalty.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
